annotation.TEXT: Even though this is an obvious thing to point out: I feel there was a heavily missed opportunity to have us fight the thing in the background. Skeletor up there at least looks like he could have some threatening attacks, as opposed to walking at you.

Similar to the rest of his incarnations, I found the final version of Dark Man to be even easier than the one from the original game. He still has Dark Man 2's shield, but it fires out so far and frequently that he may as well not have it at all. The only remotely difficult thing about this fight is that he's weak to Fuma, which is still annoying to control when you're trying to avoid something.

Until someone makes a decent modification of him to make it so that he actually does something, Dark Man 2 will always be my most hated boss in the entire franchise. I've said it before and I'll say it again: I absolutely hate enemies whose only purpose is to get inside your sprite so that you can't hit them. Even more so, it's just downright lazy design in general, to the point where this could barely be qualified as a boss.

Time to move on to the point I honestly haven't been looking forward to. In my opinion, the castle stages in this hack (or rather, almost every hack for that matter) starts to go a bit downhill. I don't know what it is about these fortress stages sometimes, but more often than not, they're generally nowhere near as fun as the 8 main stages.

Much like the Robot Masters, Dark Man's incarnations didn't receive too many changes. The first one is no longer bound to the floor, which lets you slide underneath him in case he gets too close. His projectiles also bounce around the room now, which actually leaves him more open to attacks when compared to his original version (his shots linger around for longer, meaning he stays in place while they're on-screen).

Dark Man 3 hasn't changed too much, aside from some of the paths his projectiles take. Much like the previous "boss" however, you can take advantage of his AI by abusing his weakness, thereby catching him in a loop. This one doesn't even require platforms to pull off either.

Starting off the fortress with a wave rider segment doesn't help much in those regards. I never liked the one in the original game, and was pretty relieved that it didn't seem to be in this hack...until I got to this point. It's not terrible by any means, but it's still one of those things that the stage could probably do without.

For this particular stage...I can't help but get a Mega Man Legends vibe from this place, at least to some extent. I only ever played a little bit of the first game on the PS1, but some of those tiles remind me of the underground sections and a few of the enemies.

I'm going to be perfectly honest: That thing right there is the main reason why I don't like this castle. In theory, taking Dark Man 2's shield and making it into a separate hazard is an interesting idea. The execution however, is downright annoying. These things home in on your position at high speed, and they deal a lot of damage in the process. Thankfully, this is the only stage in this hack where they show up.
